Add that girl and this guy who will become a couple, but didn't, but will become a predictable pair with supporting characters who also have become predictable couples who are as helpful as that chicken called "Jonathan" in progressing the story, then throw in the coming-of-age theme which sicks of coming-of-age Young-Adult, mention "romance" in the theme to give viewers an illusion that they're watching something romantic, plus a bit of a supernatural plot-element about “future fragments” that is as moot as that American author’s Young-Adult genre sparklepires, and you get this dramatic slice-of-life "romantic" thing that's massively plot-driven.

Even if you put Furukawa Seria, Saori Hayami, Risa Taneda, Shimizaki Nobunaga, Osaka Ryota, and Yamashita Daiki themselves here as characters, it would not matter at all because the storyline will just drive itself like a confounded Google Car and will still arrive at the same plot development towards the conclusion or ending--this is what a MASSIVE plot-driven story means. It's a Google Car in analogy.



CHARACTERS: 4

One badly-written character I’ve ever come across is this Kakeru. Because let me put it this way. If you want to look cool and indifferent at the same time, you have to be Setsuna F. Seiei. For that to happen, you have to pilot a Gundam in world war 50, which will never happen in our lifetime. So at least, you got to have the chuunibyou syndrome, which might excuse your actions, but if the theme itself is “coming-of-age” then having chuunibyou won’t work because you have act as 12 until the last episode. Hence, Kakeru’s actions is like…being schizophrenic, because having chuunibyou is simply not an excuse with the given storyline, and you can only be cool and aloof if you’re a war-torn individual in a war-torn situation in a war-torn world, or have enough supporting elements and concepts seen in fantasy-, psychological- and action-themed anime for the character to act up as that, let’s say Hunter-X-Hunter for example, or Darker than Black—both anime in which the situation calls for it.

Put that character concept in a slice-of-life and he’s downright schizoid—and yes, there’s a reason why I’m saying this, er, I don’t want to spoil it. But we both know that he does seem to sleep in a tent, outside of his own and his dad’s and his mom's home. Thus, he might be in a chuunibyou-mode imagining he’s Setsuna F. Seiei sleeping in the Exia’s cockpit, just that Setsuna F. Seiei doesn’t do that and doesn’t have, er, well, you’ll see.


Next, we have Touko, who as the main character, is as complex as glass…no, not really. She only relies in the future and is currently detached to the present. Thus, she could not do much and didn’t do much at all. It’s like she’s waiting for the writer to finish up with the episode and come to the next. You see her making calls and talking to her friends. But you take her out of the picture, and the story is still fine on its own.


Then we have the predictable pair Sachi and Hiro, who also can’t make progress because, although she did made Hiro to approach her and vice-versa as Hiro wanted to, but instead some other things or events happened, and thus the next progressive thing to do is to cancel some other events, and think what they shall read next. Sure, there were some other stuffs going on between them but it always ends up with something to do with books, even if they were talking about the moon.


Then we also have Yukinari and Yanagi, who had a progress, but for some reason the progress itself ran away and was never seen again. Hence, they’re stuck from the development. Instead, what we have are the two of them being indecisive and beating-around-the-bush with their emotional reasons that doesn't blend with the story--and then, the writer just lost it and concluded that their parents were married to each other to begin with, therefore they' are step-siblings.

Then there's Touko's little sister, Hina, who likes to go outside in a swimsuit. And that has entirely nothing to do with the plot. Even the reason where Touko and company doesn't like Kakeru who was causing them to drift has nothing to do with the plot either. They just all drifted on their own.


Then, somewhere in this chaos, the writer of Glasslip inserted the word "romance" as one of the themes.


And then, we go back to Kakeru and Touko, who, for a reason to exist, they must have been hit with the "similar attraction theory" thus they understand each other.

And so they agreed on that.

Later on the episodes, they again agreed that they don't agree they understand each other. And the story went on to the last episode. Some reviews in MAL says it's forced but it was not just forced, it was like the writer must have wrote the script while eating a rat.


All in all, the characters seem to be talking to each other, communicating, but are not interacting at all. And if they do talk, the events are already pre-determined so it doesn't matter if they talk about the moon, or fireworks, or books, or even a Hyundai, because the plot will just unfold itself as to what happens next. That's plot-development without the interaction, input and effect of the characters. It’s like talking to a fax machine. But this is a badly-written type of story so we should understand it as a badly-written story.

An American author came up with something very much like this and was able to get away with her characters she named Edward and Bella, and it worked in the same manner as feces working its way out of your large intestine and to your rectum.



ART = 10

Obviously, the art has nothing to do with the storyline so I'll rate it as 10 as this is made by Pony Canyon and P.A. Works.



SOUND = 5

I really don’t think seiyuu-wise is talk-worthy here. Sure there’s Saori Hayami on this, and she’s also in Tari-Tari, and I love her as Haqua in TWGOK and Tsuriko in AnoHana. But the entire Glasslip’s plot is driven like a Google Car. Not only there's Saori Hayami on this, there's also Risa Taneda, and neither of them can alleviate how badly-written this is. It has happened to some anime before that has Kana Hanazawa or Haruka Tomatsu on it and it will happen again.

Opening and ending songs are pretty much coming-of-age-esque, so we just leave it as that. Forever.



ENJOYMENT = 3

Can’t enjoy it at all. The only drive I have why I finished watching this was because of Saori Hayami and Risa Taneda, and that I have one more anime to add to my list here in MAL. Yet for the sake of other people to open up their minds on this...thing, you can enjoy this like the Google Car, where you can watch anime or cut your nails or read an otaku magazine while it drives for you. It’s always subjective in the end, this. In the end, it’s you who’ll decide subjectively and opinionated on how miserable or acceptable Glasslip is.



OVERALL = 4

After watching more than half of the entire 13-episodes, I get the feeling that the animators, the people hired and tasked to animate this miserable thing, must have realized that they all are completely wasting their time.

As I’ve said, Glasslip is like a Google Car. It's so driven by itself that there's no other input needed, not even the characters'.

And oh, even after watching it 'til the end, I still don’t get what’s with those future fragments...and the voice of the future.

It sounded something Relena Peacecraft or Marina Ismail would say, just not literally.



Verdict: Sure, the plot has the potential by default, but only in the creative mind of a writer who knows how a dramatic slice-of-life coming-of-age themed story is made.

I was kind of surprised to see that Glasslip scored lower than Tokyo ESP this season. It wasn't a great anime, but I don't feel it deserves less than a 6- at least not by MAL standards. The reviews seem to be overwhelmingly negative- a lot of 2's, 3's, etc, which I think is kind of ridiculous, because it makes me wonder where complete technical failures like Zettai Junpaku Majou Shoujo and Mars of Destruction are supposed to reside on the scale. If Glasslip, despite it's beautiful animation and sound, is brought down to a 2 by it's faults in story telling, then there simplyis room for the truly terrible anime to exist on the same scale. Anyway, let's talk about Glasslip. 


The first problem with Glasslip is likely its attempt at subtlety. There is a very fine line between conveying a message with few words, and saying a few words to pretend you have a message. There are a lot of really "deep" sounding lines in Glasslip- things no teenager would ever rightly say, or that are too purposefully vague to be meaningful. It takes a lot of thinking to work out coherent theories for what exactly was happening in Glasslip, and even when you come upon something you think is consistent, it's really just conjecture; the show doesn't give us, as the audience, enough to work with. We know that there's some strange love triangle (square, pentagon, hexagon- I've lost count) going on, and in the end, it feels sadly unresolved. We can speculate as to what the characters were thinking and feeling, but because the showed decided to be so vague, we can't say for sure. Sometimes that's not a bad thing... here, it just comes off as confusing. 


As for further criticism... It was hard to relate to the characters at times, especially the main girl. She's quirky for the sake of being quirky, and naive to the point where you wonder if she's "all there". In the last few episodes, the storytelling aspect of the show really falls apart. A lot is left unexplained. There was a long buildup with no climax, and I think that's what throws a lot of people off.I n the end, you get the feeling that there was never a correct answer to the question the plot proposes, and that is very unsatisfying. It feels like the author wrote a story that was complex, but never had a way to tie it all together. I'm not sure how it was all explain in the light novels, or if the endings differed, or if the anime was just too short to cover the entire story- but on its own, it really doesn't stand up to criticism. 


Now for some praise. The show had beautiful art and sound. It wasn't the best I've ever seen, but it was well above average- especially the scenery. It looks a lot like Nagi no Asukara, and that's a good thing. The anime's main faults are its storytelling- it has the technical aspects down. And despite all of the flaws I've mentioned above, I didn't hate the story. It was needlessly vague at points, but their was, in fact, a fair bit of character development over the course of the anime. The change in their relationships is actually fairly coherent, although the reasoning is never clearly stated. In fact, if they had thrown out the whole "magical" aspect of the show, it probably would have benefited. The main plot was clumsy, but the character dynamics were alright. 


I also wasn't very bored when I was watching Glasslip. As I approached the last episode, I had a sinking feeling that nothing was going to be resolved, and that was immensely disappointing- but otherwise, I never thought the series got too stale. It was fairly fast paced, and a lot happened between episodes. I think that's another thing that makes the story somewhat hard to follow; the passage of time isn't very clearly explained, although it's obvious that several weeks must be passing between episodes. Still, it kept me entertained, and I think that's a principle value of anime. 


There are better dramas you can watch. If you want action or something a bit more exciting, this obviously isn't the place to look. Glasslip isn't a great anime, but it wasn't that bad. It sits anywhere between a 6.5 and 7 for me.

It’s rather hard to swallow to think that Glasslip whom I had high expectations for turned out to be this warped.

Ordinarily I don't feel the need to review anime. If something is great, chances are someone else has already discovered it and published that fact. But Glasslip drove me to join the crowd warning against watching this pathetic excuse for a romance/slice-of-life show with a touch of fantasy/supernatural.
The reasons why this show was terrible have been well covered by other reviewers, but in short:
* The characters are annoying, flat, and/or unmemorable.
* There is essentially zero character development.
* Again and again, plot elements are introduced only to have exactly zero effect on the plot or characters.
* Oh, wait, there is no plot. Or at least, the"plot" is simply a series of scenes stitched together with no particular ordering to them.\n
* At random points, the animation (when there is animation, and not just heads with moving mouths) goes into an overly artistic freeze-frame mode for no good reason. Pretty? Yes, but it's not even relevant to the story (see previous point).\n\n
The list goes on. Which is pathetic. P.A. Works is perfectly capable of turning out well-written, well-animated, enjoyable anime that can also stand as meritorious works of storytelling. They did it with Nagi no Asukara last year, certainly. This time, though, they went with an original story, and they seem to have skimped on the writing budget.\n\n
Glasslip was just…disappointing, for a number of reasons. It could have been good. It could have been great. But at this point, the only reason I can think of for watching it is the beautiful animation. With no characters to speak of and a plot that spends the entire season spinning its wheels, there's nothing else going for it.

Let me just start off by saying that this was the most boring anime I have ever watched. There were some good aspects but they were completely ruined by the awful story overall. This anime starts off pretty well. The animation is beautiful. There are two people who can see "fragments of the future" when they look at glass or do something special or whatever. This makes sense and seems pretty interesting. 
After this, it all goes down hill. There are 2 people with the seeing the future ability, a girl and a boy. The girl main character has a group of friends, and thesefriends pretty much crush on each other and create a ton of stupid drama that 1, has no relevance, 2, is boring, and 3, doesn't have any significance whatsoever. The boy main character moves in from another town and is quiet and somewhat rude. The boys in the group of friends are jealous of his good looks. After this, the girl crushes on the guy and they almost completely throw the storyline of "seeing the future" away. Everyone in the group freaks out when they see another person with their crush, and this gets extremely annoying. They added no depth at all, killed the plot of the future seeing(the only interesting part), and focus only on girls crushing on boys. There are no funny parts, the girl is a wimp, the voice acting is decent at best, and there were no turning points in the plot that were actually important. Furthermore, this anime drags on and on and on. Watching this anime became a chore for me. I had to force myself to continue watching it because it got so ridiculously boring.

Future will never be changed.
Yep. Maybe? But how can we be sure. Glasslip is a very interesting anime, it talks about the future that everyone wanted to see, wanted to control and wanted to grab, but in reality, Future lies at the things we really loved the most.
Touko's character might be a typical girl who fell inlove at first sight at Kakeru, but to tell you the truth it is more than a typical love story. This one is more like a rubik's cube, you cannot get what they really want until you finished the whole series.

And I love the opening song. SERIOUSLY! A summer vibe song!!! XD

Having been used to PA Works whipping out quality titles like Hana-Saku Iroha and Nagi no Asukara, it was a given that I was going to be tempted to try Glasslip out. At first glance, the premise seemed intriguing on paper as female lead Toko has the ability to see visions of the future through glass and a young man named Kakuru arrives in her home town for the summer that shakes things up with the relationships between Toko and her friends as he claims to be searching for her through hearing her voice, implying he may have some sort of supernatural ability like Toko.I would think that more concerning Kakeru and Toko's connection to each other would be revealed throughout the course of the series, and we may see things shaken up with Toko and her friends with an outsider mingling with them.


Sadly though, none of this really comes to pass as the biggest pitfall to Glasslip as a whole is that nothing really happens. We get little to no development with the characters and their relationships and their depth is rather limited, killing any interest one would have in caring for any bonds they have with one another or the characters on an individual level. Nothing in the plot really advances either as things with Toko and Kakeru's abilities never really lead to anything and nothing is ever delved into over the nature of their abilities nor why they have them, even with the title's occasional dropping of teases something may happen via Toko's visions. The storytelling here feels rather lazy and underwhelming, easily being the worst title I've seen come from PA Works to date.


The only high point to Glasslip comes from its visuals. Like many titles from PA Works, the scenic shots are quite pleasing to see with vast and detailed shots of the countryside, mountains and forests that sport vivid, bright color and depict differing times of day beautifully. Character designs are on the plain side, but sport just as much visual detail as the settings with unique features such as clothing and hair accessories. The animation in the series featured fluid movement regularly throughout the title's run as characters move about and go through with their daily routines like swimming or jogging.


Glasslip is easily one of the year's most disappointing titles considering the reputation PA Works had built among fans for the number of quality titles they've animated. With the plot and characterization to the series leading nowhere throughout its run, the series is a big waste of time that one shouldn't bother watching through unless you seek disappointment out of what you wish to see.

Glasslip is great! It makes for a great wallpaper or screensaver. If it were part of a tourist promotional video or a commercial, it'd be quite excellent. Oh, as an anime, you ask? Not so much. It's almost like someone conceived of nice art with music and  then forgot it would be broadcast as an anime. 
The show is done by PA Works, a studio that often frustrates me to no end with their work but often prove rewarding to watch in the end. Their shows have a lot of potential but often encounter some very strange decision making. Glasslip has the frustrating part,but unfortunately much less of the rewarding part. 


On a conceptual level, Glasslip's story revolves around themes of loneliness and the desire for companionship as well how time is fleeting-- one lives in a moment that won't be there any more. There's also the concept of change brought by another new introduced element, most notable by one of the cast.  Glass, reflections, and fragments are key motifs in the story. There's all kinds of foreshadowing everywhere, many of it rather subtle and well done, so the plot progression isn't actually that rocky, convoluted, or contrived. 


Sounds like a masterwork right? Well...


The problem is the series forever remains a tease. Stuff gets revealed and the foreshadowing turns out to progress the plot, except it doesn't really lead to a result I care about. Should I feel for what happened? What am I supposed to think? Glasslip just packs its bags and runs. In the end, nobody really cares! 


Maybe the show was to be low key. After all, human events of daily life aren't dramatic, and things just happen without many others caring. And to be fair, a lot of Glasslip is extremely idyllic and relaxing thanks to the soothing music and nice backgrounds and characters just doing mundane tasks. But that's why we often have drama so stuff is fun to watch. You don't want your audience to fall asleep!


However, some works want you to leave it up to yourself to think of your own conclusions. I think it's a cop out, but others may like the journey being more important than the destination. Unfortunately, Glasslip sabotages itself with its greatest problem-- the dialogue. The interactions sometimes range from inane to flat out insane, almost to the point where you're wondering if they're playing homage to The Room or something. The series tries repeatedly to claim that the cast members are a circle of friends but there's too many scenes where they just keep sprouting exposition to each other-- and they really don't seem to show much concern for each other. Some friends to have, huh?


The characters individually are actually not too bad. They are  often paired with another character where they have  relationships that are actually dynamic (too bad the group as a whole isn't). In them, they have to deal with their own insecurities and awkwardness, which generates conflict and drama. This is actually handled better than many over dramatic and over the top series. Most of them grow and reach some kind of revelation about themselves and the people around them.


Although the side characters tend to be more well developed in this regard; I really don't know what the heck the 2 main leads were doing often. Glasslip also features a decent supporting cast such as the parents and siblings that I feel carries the show because they help the main cast feel like actual people. And of course, all hail Lord Jonathan the Chicken as well. I do feel however, that the developments could have been done in a concise manner, because parts of it got repeated and dragged over a bit too much for a 13 episode series. 



I think what really kept me around was the art. Those glass making scenes (which I wonder why there isn't more of) are spectacular, and they actually make good use of the lighting and stuff especially when venturing into one of the plot elements. It also seems to change in mood-- the show started out insanely bright and slowly got darker as people got into conflicts... and then we have winter. The only problem here is that the animation is a bit weird and often just has stills for no good reason, proving that every time Glasslip does something great, it must do something awful to counter it.


Personally, I liked the art for the characters as well. They're a bit better than the 2 big eyes +line for a mouth +0.5 nose moestuff that I normally see, though I tend to like moe anyways. They should watch out for those sharp chins though. 


Speaking of sound, the anime isn't bad. The opening song was pleasant to listen to every time, the ED song... not as much. Voice acting I thought was decent, well, except for Touko's ehhhhhh noise. Saori Hayami did a particular good job of bringing out the character of Yanagi.


Finally, a double edged sword comes from PA Works's insular references. The chickens and the "artsy" stills are reference to the studio's work True Tears, also by the same director. You should probably be watching that instead of Glasslip.


Overall, the show's pretty inoffensive. It did make me somewhat sad though that this show could have been so much more if some care where made to the editing  but it decides to end up like this.  Such a pity, but reality is not measured in potential but what actually happened. At least it made me laugh, sometimes intentionally but often unintentionally. You could do a lot worse than Glasslip IMO, but I cannot recommend this to anyone.

I've been reading reviews for quite some time on this show now, and no one here on MAL seems to get the point of Glasslip. When the top reviews have scores like 2 or 3, either something is wrong or the show is just that bad, which is not the case here
One thing to remember is that this review is based on my opinions and perspectives of the show, you don't have to agree nor disagree, you have only to respect it
Story: -/10
I CAN'T rate the story of this show, simply because it does not matter, it can't be bad or good because telling astory is not the point of it. When it came out, many people thought "Hey, that's another boy meets girl romance right here" and it is only fair to think that, although the show DOES present this particular plotline, it is not to be thrived for, it is not to be expected or hoped. Glasslip show us "situations" and people dealing with them. When I first moved out of my parents house, I found myself deeply frustrated by how hard it could be to fit in any group, that's our set of "main" characters and what they hope to show. They show someone who just arrived in town, being rejected by every one of the group members but one girl, he finds something in common with her, he looks for her and he also asks himself "Why her?" Those are feelings that I can't describe better than the show did and although that was the only "situation" I was able to identify myself, after doing it, I was able to see the rest of the show such as listed:


- Recovery from an injury/illness

- "Loving" more than one people

- Incest (to some extent, I know they are not brother and sister but the guilt as well as the pressure is there)

- Bisexuality


Art and Sound: 10/10


Ok, judge me, I LOVED the music and the art, it was mainly the reason I watched it, those "printscreens" in glass and the violin solos, truly amazing, I felt really good most of the times watching it


Characters: 7/10


I can't say too much about them, cause there is really not much to talk about, as far as the melancholy Takeru express, I could very much relate, and I can't tell too much about the others for the reasons I listed in Story. Since the characters are not there to tell you a story but only to describe a situation, I can't see too much error on the characters themselves, as they are not supposed to be "alive". You are supposed to see yourself in that situation, so It would be unwise to make the characters too deep, instead, they are simple, with nothing standing and shinning


Enjoyment: 6/10


I did enjoy watching it once I realized it was not about a story, it ends how it starts and that is totally fine. It came, showed me situations, and left.


Overall: 7/10


If not for the amazing sound and artstyle, I would give this a 6. It certainly isn't your conventional romance anime or big tears drama, but it speaks to you in a certain way. It made me feel really good about me leaving my parents house, and now that I've came back and will be leaving again shortly (hopefully) I might even watch it again, to make sure, not to make as many mistakes as I did back then

Ok, so I'm sure their have already been like a hundred reviews for how bad this anime, and mine may pander to that group, but I have to agree this anime was a giant disappointment.
Story: 3/10
The story follows Touko Fukami, a wannabe glass artisan who divides her time between spending time with her friends in a café and helping her father in his glass shop. Then all of sudden one day she meets this boy named Kakeru Okikura who can see into the future, and she somehow begins to see into the future as well. Unfortunately this plot never gets enough time to develop andis ultimately brushed off during the final episode.


The subplots of this anime mostly consist of the relationships between the friends and the presence of a love hexagon. The love hexagon basically follows Touko likes Kakeru while her friend Yuki likes her, Yuki's stepsister Yanagi likes him, Kakeru likes Touko, and Sachi, Touko's best friend likes her and their other friend Hiro.  The feelings that each character has for their significant other are revealed throughout the anime, but considering how forced and unnatural these confessions came across as, I honestly couldn't care about any of their relationships.


Characters: 2/10

The characters in this anime were very flat and one dimensional. They also don't do anything worth making them likeable. First we have, the main protagonist, Touko Fukami, she wants to become a glass artisan and can see into the future apparently, that's all you need to no about her. Then there's Kakeru Okikura, he's best described as a loner who can see into the future, as well. There's Yuki who likes Touko and runs. There's Yanagi who likes Yuki and starts running. Finally there's Sachi who is bisexual having feelings for Touko as well as Hiro whom she ends up choosing and that's really all you need to know about him other than he works in the café they hang out in. 


Art: 7/10/Sound: 5/10

The art and animation for this anime is really the only redeeming quality. Glasslip was produced by PA Works who have done an excellent job producing much more quality anime such as: Angel Beats! and Another.

The sound was average at best, the OP was cute, but also generic. The ED was also generic and nothing special.


Enjoyment: 4/10

I did not enjoy this anime all that much. I was quite disappointed by it, as it seemed to have a lot going for it such as a great animation studio but unfortunately it did not meet my expectations


Overall: 4/10

If you're looking for a great slice of life or friendship anime, I highly recommend you watch the Clannad series, Angel Beats!, or this seasons' Ao Haru Ride or Barakamon, they are much better than this shit.

I would love to just state how bad I think Glasslip is, but instead, I'll point out the key moment that I realised it was going to be bad and actually give a detailed explanation of my issues with it as a show:
Episode 1, first 3 minutes prior to the OP theme. We have animation of a train, then random people wandering around, we then flash cut through the cast, with their names posted by them. Whoever decided this scene should exist, realised in retrospect that the characters and story was so anomalous that it was required to make sure their names were printed onscreen for a matter of seconds before they were rendered irrelevant.


This was the absolute worst opening to any anime I've seen for a long, long time. Nothing was established, we have no idea who these people are and they showed no intention of progressing past that point.


As someone who's studied film, worked on indie projects and a couple of uni projects, (storyboarding, scripting, re-writes) it was embarrassing to witness and turned me off the show instantly. It set a tone that nothing was important or of interest from the get go and stayed there. It's almost literally anti-direction 101; The initial establishing shot for the show establishes literally nothing.


How the direction and composition of the series can be so bad, I have no idea. The director for it is not bad by any means (Nishimura, Junji), but he has done a number of 'non-event' romance comedies; the second half of Ranma 1/2 (episodes 70 onwards) is what I knew him best for, but he also did some pretty good shows as well; True Tears, Simoun, You're Under Arrest! and more. So, while I could see the show not being the greatest, it should have at least been good, as the director is collaborating with Horikawa, Kenji, the producer of anime such as Jin-Roh, Evangellion and Angel Beats and helps explain why the show looks so good, despite the way it goes nowhere.


So here is the problem I noticed: Rika SATOU (佐藤 梨香) is listed specifically as the series compositor. This is a woman who's mostly known for key animation and in-between animations on shows and has no record of doing more. However, the shows she's worked on in-between and key animation with have had very good levels of animation. If that is so, why is she working on series composition? I have no idea.


How important is series composition you ask? Series composition works as such:


The Series Compositor writes the overarching story for an anime show. They are the one that the director and script writers turn to for their plots, stories and how it will all link together. They decide where a story will start, how it will flow, what episodes will occur where and how it will tie together. It's then down to the directorial staff/episode script writers to fill in the episodes as requested, while the series compositor decides what will or will not work from episode to episode. The compositor often writes a number of episodes, or at least outlines for them, but they rarely write the entire thing themselves. Think of them basically as the director of the directors; they are the first and last word in all story and plotting decisions and it is the job of those below them to put it all together.


TLDR/Conclusion: Given that the director and producer of the show are veterans, who also collaborated on True Tears together (PA Work's first independent show), Rika Satou has probably been handed this job as a way to get into a more important position within the anime creation procedure (she worked with the producer on Angel Beats and she's worked with PA Works a few times before) and has probably been given too much free-reign over what happens.


The series showed some potential with the ideas it has failed to touch on, but goes no where story-wise or development-wise. The pacing is bad and the entire show feels discombobulated as a result. It feels as though it's been put together by a rookie, or someone with no experience in overarching plot work. Thus explaining my conclusion.

I bet many people would had high expectations for this anime, like me from the beginning as Glasslip was made by P.A Works and they made some really great animes such as Nagi No Asukara, Hanasaku Iroha and Angel Beats. I expected this anime to be the next 'Nagi No Asukara', for the settings and the characters, but I was wrong.
At the start, it was pretty engaging, so I decided to keep watching. Gradually as the series unveiled, my views on this anime began to degrade. My overall thoughts of the anime is complete utter s***! Let's now break this down into sections.
Story: 
The plotof Glasslip takes place in a seaside town called Hinodehama. Touko's family runs a business of glass-working and Touko hangs out with her friends at a cafe called Kazemichi. A transfer student called Kakeru then comes into the scene, which reminded me of Nagi No Asukara, (when Tsumugu came along). The show was slow-pacing, but I expected slow-pacing animes would result in a very memorable one such as Steins; Gate,  but this anime was a very big exception. Overall, nothing happens pretty much throughout the whole series. There wasn't any dramatic moment, so I was really bored for almost the whole time, watching Glasslip, The story was the weakest point of the series, along with the characters. 

1/10


Art:

The art was indeed the strongest point of the anime. The scenery and setting were really appealing and beautiful to the eyes. Enough said.

8/10


Sound:

The music was pretty good, in particular the OP, due to the tone. The ED was ok. The tracks throughout the series were mostly classical music and from what I notice, they are mostly compositions from Frederic Chopin. It's not bad using tracks of other artists/composers, but it would be better if the anime used original soundtrack, as they would stand out more. 

6/10


Character:

As I said in the 'Story' section, the characters were also the weakest point in the entire series. Many of the characters have developed little to nothing, in personality and actions. The series does not allow us to learn more about each of the characters and we cannot see the characters changing throughout. So overall, the characters were not really memorable and that you could easily forget them after you completed the series.


Enjoyment:

Overall, I didn't really enjoyed this project from P.A Works, unlike Nagi No Asukara and Angel Beats. I was really looking forward to another great romance slice of life, but it didn't turned out what I expected to be. Nothing dramatic happens in the series, so I wasn't on the edge of my seat (NOT EVEN ONCE!) and I barely understood the relationship between the characters. Even though it's a slice of life anime, the characters just literally play their role in their daily lives. Other slice of life animes, such as Clannad and K-On is much better than this.


Conclusion: 

Story: Very boring and neutral (1/10 Pathetic)

Art: Nice-looking and colourful (8/10 Very Good)

Sound: Decent, but could have been better (6/10 Fair)

Character: Little to no development throughout the series (1/10 Pathetic)

Enjoyment: Bored for almost the entire time (2/10 Dreadful)


OVERALL SCORE: 3/10 (POOR)

This will be a short piece on my own opinion about this show. P.A Works has produced many original works in the past, like Charlotte, Angel Beats, and others. To start off, the art and music were splendid, the only true "good" things about this show. The music is catchy and enjoyable, and P.A Works never disappoints with their animation. Now, the worst part of this show is the story. I really wanted to like and understand the show, but with the horrendous writing, it was impossible. With an unexplained supernatural aspect, and pointless drama, love triangles and of the sorts. This just continuously takesaway from each episode. As there always will be some pointless drama caused by simple reasons. I thought that you couldn't screw up writing a slice-of-life show, but Glasslip really surprised me. Characters, what can I say, a mysterious transfer student comes into a group of friends. Strange things began to happen, can't get more generic than that. Using generic character archetypes are fine, but trying to pretend that there was any meaningful character development is pointless and just plain deceptive in nature. There was really nothing interesting with anyone except the transfer student, and that's because we don't know a whole lot about him. We get some clues, and the show tries to give hints, but the execution of this is terrible and it would of just been better to explain upfront what's going on. I personally still found enjoyment in this show however, as the confusion and urge to try to understand what was going on motivated me to keep watching to the end. I have to say that it was a waste of time, as nothing really happened. If your a fan of slice-of-life, this might be a show to watch, but as there are thousands of others, this is something that should just be simply ignored.

It is my habit to read reviews before I complete a series and judging from the reactions, I'm officially putting this on hold until I find reason to complete this show. Honestly, the art and the synopsis got me into this anime, and I was hoping to get clarity on the ending.
-WARNING: CONTAINS A SPOILER-
The story did start as good and is quite interesting, but as the story progresses, it completely lost me. I was like, what's already happening? The plot development is moving too fast that I think the author missed to justify each episode. 
Drama is too forced. Seriously, why on earth wouldyour friend try to break your romantic relationship just for the sake of keeping your group together? (Sorry, just got until ep. 9  and I won't elaborate any further)\n\n
I think one other factor that made the forced drama is trying to incorporate supernatural plot that is not justified why it has to happen. And if it's you who can see bad things that'll happen in the future, won't you try to give a warning? As I see it, the lead character doesn't trust her friends.\n\n
I really tried liking this anime that's why I made it to more than half of the series, but I won't force myself anymore to complete this anime.

The art and animation is good. It's bright and very fitting for the setting for a slice of life genre anime. However that was all the appeal I could find for this anime.
There were elements in this anime that were poorly executed and just felt completely scripted rather giving a natural feeling. There was no clear foreshadowing and a lot of things that came off as a surprise were supposed to be obvious. Even the drama ruins it's own genre.
The characters felt emotionless, and no I'm not talking about the one or two stoic characters, the voice actors seemed to have almost no emotion whenthey talk in my opinion. They change their tones, but I feel nothing expressed through their voices until the characters are pushed to an extreme. The characters themselves can't be saved from their plain personalities. But then again, none of them were likable anyways so that doesn't matter.\n\n
The soundtrack is not great, but it's not noticeable. It's supposed to help reflect and build an atmosphere of a scene but fails miserably. From the opening I got that it was a happy feeling anime, but that sure isn't it. Most of the time it just falls silent and it just doesn't feel right.\n\n
All in all, Glasslip has been one of the most boring pieces I have ever seen. To summarize my thoughts - Stay the hell away because there are much better series to watch, as a result my final score is 6/10.

This anime is not for people who like their plot lines to be delivered on a golden plate. That is why it gets so much more hate than it deserves. I get that a good amount of viewers out there don't like to think on their own, use their imagination and see whats underneath the surface, but it's nevertheless a pity to see a fine show drown with the mass of dense and jaded folks.
What it has going on for me personally is a calming pace, a gorgeous city, CHICKENS and a story, that will ask you to put some thought into it and drawconclusions on your own. (if you like Shakespear or are into philosophy, yet enjoy a bit of innocent romance, you should be set up well with this one)


Art: 8/10

This anime is pretty, especially landscape wise. I'm not a huge fan of the choice in their character art, but it wasn't terrible either. Just a bit too generic. 


Story: 9/10

I really enjoyed how puzzled I felt. The plot is challenging, not so much in a deep, intellectual way like Steins/Gate, but more along the emotional intelligence line. I would have liked a couple of more episodes to flesh it out better and get more time with the semi-main characters (though to be fair, it does try it's best to spread it's focus equally).


Music: 7/10

The opening and ending themes were fine, hitting the right keys to match the show. However, the tracks that were used within the anime did not stay with me, moreover I got a little annoyed by the same piano track being used over and over and that's coming from someone who really loves classic music. 


Characters: 8/10

It's rare for me to enjoy the majority of characters in an anime, to be frank.

This is the case for Glasslip. I was especially thankful to find no moe personalities or annoying people with high pitched voices, yelling for attention every 2 minutes. I especially enjoyed Yuki and Yanagi and would have liked to see more about them, but oh well. Sadly, Kakeru, as one of the most important figures for the plot, was a little let down for me. He didn't seem to develop his own drive, never seem to be really there with all his heart and it made it difficult for me to relate to Toukus feelings. Yet he probably felt the same about himself and it makes sense again. 


The show left me with a quiet, warm feeling and this is why I'm writing this review in the first place. 

I advice those, who like animes, that will not give you every answer at hand and make things as obvious as possible to give it a go. Everyone else, please pass by and look for something else. (BAKA!) ;)

Coming after Nagi no Asukara (which was rather rather highly), everyone expected Glasslip to be a P.A. Works series which could rival that of the former. Turns out it was far from being able to do so. However, criticism of this series is rather subjective and really depends on the viewer himself/herself. 
STORY: 6/10
To put it very simply, this show is basically about teenage romance which has sparked off among a group of close friends. That's pretty much about it. They then spend the next 13 episodes contemplating on their feelings about one another. I'm giving this section a 6 because, at least they triedto think of something. It's not like they really threw in a random storyline just to last 13 episodes; the plot was there, but it was probably not strong enough. 


The element of Romance is pretty commendable in my opinion. In fact, the primary reason I had watched this series (and continued on) was because of the Romance. 


ART: 9/10


"Wow! Amazing!" was what I thought when I first saw the visuals and PVs for Glasslip. And it certainly lived up to expectations. The art was brilliant, as they illustrated the sceneries and places of Hinode well. Needless to say, the characters were good-looking too. If there's anything I would take away from this series, it would be the art as it was memorable to say the least. 


SOUND: 8/10


Decent OSTs, including the OP and ED. The background music were played at appropriate times and really fitted the atmosphere and scenery of the anime. I've gotten their OST under my belt already and I have to say it rivals some of the top ones from other series. The OP and ED were fairly enjoyable as well.


CHARACTER: 6/10


On to another component of any series, the characters. As the characters are plunged into thoughts of love and their feelings, we see that every character have their explicit strengths and weaknesses. As a teenager myself, I'd have to admit that I really found the characters relatable. The problems they were going through were genuine, and I believe anyone would react like any one character in the series when faced with a similar situation. The characters won't make much of an impression in me after this, but the scenes they played out may. 


ENJOYMENT: 6/10


I wouldn't say I enjoyed every single moment of this, but to be fair there were some bits  I'd enjoyed. Those who have personally experienced genuine moments of love (first love, crushes, etc.) should find this worth watching. I probably won't be re-watching this, but I heard a LN will be coming out and I guess I won't mind checking that out. Hopefully the LN will portray the story in a much better manner than the animation. 


Overall, not the best series you will see, but in my opinion and by my standards, it's enough to clinch a 6/10.

There may be one or two small spoilers, nothing major.
The series, Glasslip, started out rocky. But many series that go places and turn out to be good sometimes do; I'll use Steins;Gate as an example. If you give a series with a rough beginning a chance it might develop into a decent, or in the case of Stein;gate, fantastic series. Glasslip does not do this,in fact I'm going to tell you don't even bother watching the first episode. From the extremely confusing and bizarre beginning, Glasslip, starts in a downward spiral. The plot is not explained to the audience, hell it does not even havea fucking plot. There is hardly anything endearing about this show.



Story 3/10- The story line starts out extremely confusing, and leaves the view in a state of bewilderment. This sense of confusion is persistent throughout the show, and leaves the viewer wanting some sort of background on the characters.



Art 7/10- If there is one decent factor about this show, it would be its art. The art is decent, nice to look at, and it is the only part of the show that the producers got right.



Characters 3/10- To me it would seem that the producers sat down and decided to make a cast of characters no one would like. It is impossible to like any of the characters, and they never develop. They never dive into why Sachi is so against Touko being with "David". Why does she feel this way, and why is it okay for her to have feelings for someone else? It's such bull shit, piss poor writing. They don't explain why, after possibly threatening her chickens, does Touko fall in love with Okikura-san. (I warned you about spoilers, but you shouldn't watch this any way's.) There is no development whatsoever. On a side note that "ehhh" noise that Touko makes every episode pisses me off.



Overall 4/10- I think that Glasslip will be a memorable anime, memorable in how truly awful it was. It will be reminisced about with other titles like School Days. So should you watch this show? No, no you should not. There are far better things to watch this season. There is no need for you to torment yourself with this, you are better than that.

My overall impression after selecting "completed" was, just what the hell did I watch?
Story: Where Glasslip fell short the most was the story, or lack there of one. There was no underlying theme or plot to the anime other than the fact that the two main characters develop some type of bond over "future fragments." A lot of things were left unanswered in the end... Like most importantly, what was the point of Jonathan and all those damn chickens?! After halfway in, I began dreading the show and just wanted to know if anything significant happened...  I'd also like to add that despite thefact that this has romance in it, I found that the interactions between the pairings were very anticlimactic and confusing. Needless to say, I was left very disappointed and found that this anime's attempt to generate a unique plot was sloppy and all over the place. 2/10


Art: I have never been disappointed in the aesthetics that Production IG shoots out. Very easy on the eyes. This anime shines the most in how there is so much attention to the detail in the art. Even though I never quite understood what the hell was going in in their "future fragments," I found that how they were showcased kept me interested enough to not consider dropping the series entirely. 9/10


Sound: Didn't hate the opening or ending songs, but I still found myself skipping through them with each episode. I honestly don't have much to say in this category since I found it to be pretty standard and no aspect of the shows music particularly staid out it me. 6/10


Character: Absolutely no character development whatsoever. There were only a couple if characters I enjoyed seeing on the screen, but everyone essentially bothered me with their unnecessary angst. Aside from Sachi and Touko, I'm even at a loss as go why these 6 characters are still good friends, since their interactions and exchanges mostly felt awkward to watch. 3/10


Enjoyment: I honestly enjoyed the fact that I no longer have to watch another episode of this show. I don't recall having anything but negative reactions to any of the episodes either. 


Overall: When the pilot episode spent about 10 minutes on a bunch of chickens should have given me the cue to not pick up this series. I would not recommend this to anyone. 3/10

-----------------------------SPOILER ALERT-------------------------------------
I already read some of negative and positive reviews earlier, and then continue to search for clue in order understanding how this anime works.
In my opinion this anime is very good in its own term. What I mean is originality (based on other previews and my experience), the main plot is indeed messed up . . . when you see it based on your current watching experience. But if you are more careful, you should see clue by clue given by author, especially in the last episode. For example, one of Kakeru quotes in last episode (in english),"When you (Touko) say nevermind, then itis important (Touko's mom said that she used to be like Touko, at the end, she experience unexpected event,contrary of her future sight), the author implicitly give clue that every "future fragment" Touko and Kakeru experience just an imagination (perhaps?) yet in the end Touko still believe that and said (which she already said at the first episode), "No matter what, the future me will overcome it" (which is she forgot how that work in the middle episode which make her so afraid about future). And remember the scene about 14 marbles with some grass on the desk?That means Touko took it again after thrown it, but where is the rest of it? perhaps she neglected the rest or gave it to Kakeru as parting gift. Either way, it is clear that she already move on. Remember that last scene when her imagination come out again? etc etc, just conclude the story with clue given by author implicitly then you can understand the story as a whole. Rather see a picture inch per inch, it will be best if you see a picture as a whole.


The other morale story is love is'nt what you always imagine (Underline word "imagine" which is the key of term "future fragment"). As you can see, every imagination Touko seen (or heard) is'nt what to be expected. For example, Touko see that Sachi and Hiro had a good time together in hospital, but in reality Sachi is'nt really see Hiro as a boyfriend (you will see the clue when the two hiking together, friendzone detected). Yuki at the end love Yanagi as family (because they are brother and sister unrelated to blood),then you sure can't see them having romantic contact. And remember when Kakeru said "I've found you" then suddenly his ability vanish? There is a term in our social life, "First Love Sight", isn't it? It is just that simple. His ability is again just imagination caused by loneliness, when he found irreplaceable friend, he feels that he will not alone again.


I will tell you my another perspective, this anime is'nt your average romance anime. It has some deep meaning in it. I'm sure the author mean it (I already watched Angel's Beats and it has deep meaning while combining with comedy).

That's conclude my reviews. thanks for reading this :)

First things first. My "reviews" system is explained on a blog entry. Which can be found through my profile.
------
I have no idea what's with the low score or why people putting so much hate on it, nevertheless here comes my point of view of this anime.
Story
I found story quite enjoyable, it was chill, cute, mysterious and eerie at times. I mean the whole slice-of-life here was done right. It was really relaxing and cute to look at romance progression. With the touch of "fragments of future" it made it a bit intriguing. Though those fragments became rather than foreseeing future, they became more of emotional"visions" and valuation.  I mean I understand them as following, that those fragments were actually reliving someones experience or feeling the possible futures, past or times that passed, were to poss, variations or hopes of what to come. So somewhat "longing future, bitter future, bitter differences". Point being, fragments felt odd and sometimes they felt even eerie for me. But overall, story was as mentioned. Relaxing and cute.


Art/sound


Well art is what I call "kyotos animation long lost sister" , meaning that they have very nice touch and feel overall of slice-of-life. While kyoto has their "quirky" shows and beautiful art, while  P.A. Works has more of "feet on their" ground, simple and pretty style with great choice of music. (meaning they also have a lot of great slice-of-life. EX: Nagi No Asakura, Shirobako, Tari Tari, Hanasaku Iroha etc..)


Sound is something I absolutely loved in this anime. Probably because I have sweet spot for piano. Piano tracks were mostly relaxing, bittersweet, colorful and pleasant. Also Nano;Ripe is always welcome. Opening was probably the part I liked the least. Rest of OST was also between average and very good.


Character


I'm not sure what to comment. I liked the them all. Only character I disliked or semi-annoyed me was the damn "tee-hee-pero" sister... that phrase of her felt so moronic. Rest of characters were between enjoyable and great. Maybe Touko wasn't that enjoyable for me. As not really my type. Point being.. all characters were "normal".. but in a enjoyable not, not in boring way. Very grounded, but very pleasant experience with the characters.


Enjoyment/Overall


So in the end, I'm not sure what the hate is about, but I personally found this anime relaxing, bittersweet and pleasant experience with a little touch of mystery (and eeriness for me)
