This is very difficult anime to review (and my first review, so bear with me). There are so many conflicting emotions that stem from this, but I will try to be succint in my summation.
Ultimately, I liked this, but I can see for sure why most people really didn't. As far as a show with entertainment goes, it had very very little, everything that I got from this anime I had to struggle and think very hard about, I did a lot of reading around to cement my own opinions about the endings and come to a marginally satisfying conclusion, but therein lies the biggestproblem. To truly like this you have to put far too much effort in and not have any real payoff beyond what you imagine.


For me, this worked because I could relate to the fears of both Kakeru and Touko, so in that sense I had a vested interest in seeing their characters grow (although again, it could be argued that they didn't particularly grow at all). The supernatural element was not explained at all and did not really have any benefit to the show, especially for a show that was basically one long metaphor. It just muddied up the waters and made it harder to understand, made the characters less believable and ultimately was a nuisance.


All that being said, I can't shake how this is staying with me, I keep thinking about it, studying the characters, their motivations, their feelings, and for me this is OK, I just wish we had a bit (OK, a lot) more explanation on the devices used in the plot.

This is the first review I've ever done, so be easy on me - hard to maybe do considering my review is kind of going against what everyone else seems to be saying.
First of all let me start by saying this is not in a million years what an example of a good teen romance should be, or a drama, or anything of the sort. This anime is a pretty little mess of genre elements that seem to have been sewed into a somewhat bearable story. But in essence, to me at least, that was almost its charm point. I've not watched an anime thatseems to work with complicated chips as much as Glasslip did.


The story was of slow pacing and with characters you seemed to fluctuate feelings towards and against. In some ways you rooted for things to go one way but after a strange or awkward event you went another. The way this anime dealt with character interaction and emotion was personally very life-like and almost realistic, despite the heavy (almost forced) emphasis on love triangles and romantic tension. Some may call them bland and a bit bare, but I for one think this kind of anime needed these sort of characters, that were also very genuine in their emotional well-state that made them 'enough'. One main point I see brought up time and time again is that of the 'time shard' plot - I have no real argument against it's place in the anime but I would have liked to see it explored a little more, as the way it was in the series almost seemed like an unnecessary add-on to try and keep the viewers interested. Whilst these are heard complaints/critiques, I like to think that this was the best way this anime could tell its unique little story.


Finally the music for both the opening and ending were very charming, and the elegant, relaxing OST throughout made it such an easy watch for me. The art style for me was also one its more pleasing points, as the nature-filled environment flooding the anime made me feel very at ease. The setting next to a seaside with the hills and fireworks definitely added to the calming feel I think the anime was trying to go for. VA was also decent and I have no real complaints there.


TL;DR, to summarise, this will not be (and has proven not to be) everyone's cup of tea. However, if you're looking for something a little bit more laid-back and non-serious before you go to bed, Glasslip may be an option for anyone interested enough. Whilst not the best in any way at all, I appreciated what the anime was trying to get at and its beautiful animation/music/VA work won me over and I give it a VERY generous score of 7.

One day, my friends and I decided to get together and binge an anime. When deciding what show to watch one of my friends suggested Glasslip. The rest of us agreed. We asked that friend if there was some kind of drinking game that we could play while watching. They said that the only drinking game we could play that will get us drunk enough to make it through this show without also dying of alcohol poisoning is to just take a shot before each episode. THIRTEEN SHOTS OF HARD LIQUOR LATER, I had three questions:
1) Wait, wasn't this supposed to be about glass blowing?

2) What the fuck was up with those chickens?

3) Why did there have to be a step-sibling romance subplot?


Calling this show a clusterfuck with no direction is an understatement.  It's like if when they were deciding what the story should be about they just handed out a multiple choice sheet to all the employees and everyone just chose "all of the above." The problem with that is that the "none of the above" bubble was above the "all of the above" bubble, so the show is about everything and nothing at the same time.


At least the art was nice and the soundtrack was pretty.

Glasslip also known(to me at least) as Nagi no asukara without the fish people xd. If you've watched NagiAsu you'll understand why I say this pretty much in the first chapter. Although NagiAsu was much better.
Story:
This was the main problem I had with the anime. By the end of the anime an explanation of what are the "future fragments" is not given and understanding what these were was the main point of the whole story.
I guess someone might say that the romance was also part of the main plot, but considering that this wasn't really developed in the story with the exception of 2 or3 scenes, I don't it counts as one.

I had a lot of questions about the anime that I was hoping to get an aswer for them, sadly the last chapter only got me more questions and almost no answer.


Art:

The art was really good, especially the background scenes, I don't really know how to explain it but it was really good. The character designs were amazing probably one of the best of the season.

This actually helped a lot while watching the anime, because as I said before the story wasn't that good.


Sound:

I really enjoyed the soundtrack of Glasslip, Akito Matsuda did an amazing job composing all these amazing pieces that go well with the scenes that these are played in.

The op was also pretty good. I don't really listen to the op and ed themes of anime more than 2 or 3 times during the whole series, with some really few exceptions and this op was one of those. I got to like it very much and pretty much listened to it every chapter. The ending theme on the other hand was ok, it wasn't bad but it certainly wasn't a memorable one.


Characters:

This was another problem with the anime. There wasn't really any character that could be memorable besides Touko and that is only because the story is basically about her and Kakeru.


This anime had really good potential, it isn't that bad of an anime it's average. I'm pretty sure there might be people that will really like this anime so I think maybe give it a chance, specially if you liked NagiAsu xd.

Glasslip has been often quoted as one of the worst anime series by many people. I feel this is a completely false statement and people who have seen many anime series will probably confirm this. There are much, much worse series out there. I actually don't even think Glasslip was a completely terrible series! And it could have been much better if it hadn't done so many things oh so wrong. This is what I'm going to discuss.
Glasslip: SoL or Drama?
Throughout watching Glasslip I felt the show constantly was jumping between drama and slice of life and it ended up being a mess. One ofmy favorite series is Nagi no Asukara, a series that came out roughly a year before Glasslip. The two series are both original series by P.A. Works and many NagiAsu fans (me included) were hoping for another series like Nagi no Asukara. Nagi no Asukara, in my opinion, is a series focused on conflict, drama. Sure there is a SoL feel in some episodes but that only lasts so long before a conflict arises, testing the characters' limit and leaving the audience hoping for the characters to overcome the events and grow as people from them. 


Glasslip does not take this course, and even if it did, the characters would ruin it. I'll talk more about that later. 


The slice of life genre stands on one thing. The characters. Without lovable and entertaining characters, the series is noting. Why would we want to watch the life of boring and unlikable individuals with nothing spectacular happening? Series that succeed in the SoL genre like Ichigo Mashimaro, Barakamon, and Non Non Biyori only succeed because people want to watch the characters. They enjoy their personalities and just watching then do mundane and simple activities is fun. 



Glasslip: Characters

As mentioned above, characters make a SoL show. The problem is every character in Glasslip was annoying and felt extremely unnatural. They even tried to rip off the characters in Nagi no Asukara. With the "quiet and mysterious new guy" character Kakeru a failed attempt to recreate Tsumugu from Nagi no asukara. And the main girl is a clumsy, cheerful, lovestruck heroine extremely similar to Manaka's character in NagiAsu. Yet somehow even trying to recreate the characters from Nagi no Asukara, I disliked every character in Glasslip, even if I love every character in NagiAsu. Actually the only character in Glasslip I liked was the main character's little sister, Hina, who had very little screen time! So watching the show I couldn't get invested in what was happening to the characters because I didn't like or care about any of them.



Glasslip: Sci-fi or not??

The most frustrating thing about Glasslip is its piss poor attempt to integrate a sci-fi or fantasy element like they did in NagiAsu. And yea, the set-up on paper is cool. A girl and boy who can tell the future through a looking glass? But what happened to that? Its mentioned here and there and then nothing. It's like a romantic drama. The characters all trying to figure out their feelings for each other in the hot summer. Hormones, a hot sun, sandy beaches! ... oh yea and some of them have this power..... They do such a poor job at this area of the show, it would make the show better if it didn't have the most interesting concept in it! As you can tell I'm pretty mad about it. The idea had so much potential and they just took a giant shit on it.



Is Glasslip a terrible unwatchable show?

No. 


But is it a show that I would recommend to someone looking for a colorful slice of life show? Or perhaps a drama-filled romance? A fantasy show about a girl seeing the future of her closest friends right before her eyes?

No, no I wouldn't. None of that.


But is it a show with pretty animation and a nice soundtrack?

Haha, yep.


In conclusion: I give Glasslip a 5/10.

I just finished Glasslip so I decide to do another review on it. Last one was on the first four episodes, this is on the complete show. So here it goes
Story- Generic slice of life story. Like in my other review I can't say much more then that. Granted I'm not a big fan of slice of life in general, but for the anime in slice of life that I have seen this is pret generic. But he story started to piss me off. Not because of the slice of life, I can live with that. It the other aspect they added to the show.The whole vision concept and power that our main MC and Kakeru (Hope to god I spelled his name right) have. It isn't never explained. They just showed glimpse and pieces of how it works. At first it was some future seeing thing but then the whole power got turned around in the final episode out of nowhere. It ended up being something different. And they barely explained that. That is my biggest gripe with it because they never fully explained how this power worked. I'm no expert in this, far from it, But I think if your going to add some supernatural power you need to explain it. Not show it, then say it might be something else and still not fully explain after you say it might be something else. Overall them not explaining that power took the story score down. Overall 3/10


Art- One of my high points in this anime, but I have a gripe with this two. Not the animation, no no no. It's the still frames. For anyone that has seen it you know what I am talking about. I don't know why but when they used the still frames all silly-hilly it pissed me off to know end. Other than that I got nothing bad to say about the background or the animation or the characters. Overall 8/10


Sound- The background music fits the theme and I really loved the opening and ending to it. And voice actors did their job. Not much else to say. Overall 8/10


Characters- While I will say these characters can be relatable, in anime, they are generic. Touko the MC who loves her friends and has a crush on David, Yanagi the girl who wants in incest love with her step brother (Kinda exaggerating that, but I sh*t you not about loving her step brother), Yuki the guy who has a crush on Touko, which isn't really returned (but has that incest direction if that completely bombed) , Hiro the cheerful jokester in the group, Sachi the quiet book reading friend who didn't want to lose any of her friends and Kakeru our mysterious transfer student who is the love interest of Touko.


Enjoyment- 7/10 I'll admit I actually enjoyed it. I'll honestly admit that much. Not higher because of the ending


Overall- 5/10 While the animation and sound is good the way it ends it without explaining the supernatural power that it tried to add to make it different from other slice of life, really ruined it for me. I'll will say though I would fully recommended this to slice of life fans. Others...not so much

The character was fine but I wish that I can understand the story more. The story doesn't express much. 
I'm disappointed because I can't understand the story and the ending sucks like shit. As I mentioned, I had my expectations high.

Ah yes, the typical love triangle anime, where a bunch of teenagers get submerged into the world of romance.  Unfortunately I sit here writing this review in distaste.  Ill start by saying the things I loved about this anime: The artwork is beautiful! The colors are reminiscent of Nagi no Asukara, and the music is light and entertaining.  
Now for the bad stuff:
This anime was on my list of anime i was excited for when it aired. I sat through the entire series because of the artwork and the few characters I did like. But other than that it was painful towatch sometimes.  The main character is distasteful, I did not like her at all, she was annoying in the slightest and never really went for anything. Static is a good word for her. The side characters however were relatively interesting. My biggest problem with this anime was the lack of development. The main characters NEVER CHANGED, they played cat and mouse the entire anime.  Needless to say I was disappointed by this anime. It leaves you feeling short of story and lack of fulfillment.

The hugely negative reviews that this show is getting is mainly because this show is aimed at a specific audience. it is neither flashy nor has twists and turns like many other anime. It is a slice of life, a very thin slice and not everyone can connect to it. In real life things do not progress fast. In real life you dont have stereotyped characters like tsunderes and danderes. In that way the characters in glasslip are very real. I do not understand why the wort of an anime or character is measured by how interesting backstory it has or the struggle of eachcharacter. Yes, those anime are inspirational and hit us hard but just because an anime caters to the ordinary people with ordinary life does not mean its bad. The artwork is brilliant in this anime btw and that is one point everyone agrees.\n
Verdict:- If you want a thriller, a plot with huge twists and turns, characters with backstory etc. stay away from this anime. If you want to enjoy mundane lifestyle and complex romantic love life of a few teenagers, this anime is for you. Personally I could connect a lot to this anime, it was almost like school life all over again and I believe many can.

The art was good.  The music was outstanding.  The characters were good, pretty typical (minus the DD's and dumb girl--which I was happy to see for a change).  I started out really loving this anime.
As indicated above, the beginning story in the beginning was unique, great, and different. I wanted to know what was happening in the story.  
Then in turned into a typical teenage romance scenario when a group is involved and I was like, okay, I can accept this, not too unique but I liked the characters.  
Then the last few episodes fell apart.  They were tooesoteric from where it had been going.  It changed back to the original story line at a 90 degree angle doing 100 mph, then the last couple episodes took another 90 degree turn to the finish line.  A finish line that I though was not in following with what the story had been telling us.  \n\n
I wanted to love this anime, it had so much potential.  I tried to love it but it just fell apart in my opinion.  There is no amount of beautiful music and artwork that could save it for me.  I finished the last episode and all I could say was, "what the heck happened?"

When I first saw the cover for this anime I really thought that I would love it. I thought it was another anime that was deep and meaningful. But it wasn't with every passing episode I found myself getting less and less interested and more and more confused. 
Character development was pretty eh, one of the things that annoyed me most was when Hiro went to the hospital and his sister was also there and she had walked out of a hospital room (her boyfriends) crying. The anime never really cleared that up. Why was she crying? What happened?
Aside from that this anime definitelycould've been longer than 13 episodes. There was a lot of potential for character development but the creators just ignored it. \n
Episode 12 was maybe what made my opinion of this anime drop to a lower score. It made me so utterly confused. I didn't understand it at all. Episode 13 was its ending. And I was wrong to have hope that in the final episode it could make up for the mistakes. But it didnt, instead I was just more confused. It didn't feel like any of the characters got closure on their stories. Except maybe Hiro and Sacchan. It didn't really explain what happened to Kakeru his tent in the backyard was just gone. Did he go on tour with his mother? What the hell man? \n
I'm not sure if I was the only one confused all through out that anime. But I hope I wasn't. There's probably a lot more I could analyze on this anime. It felt kind of like a waste watching this anime. But if I didnt I most likely would have just continued thinking I missed out on watching a good anime. I'm glad I tried It out and satisfied my curiosity. But was it worth my time? Not really. I didn't like this anime. Though this is all just my opinion and I respect those who did enjoy this anime (and their opinions).

While reading the description for Glasslip, you would think this anime is going to be great. It had so much potential. The first problem was the under development of characters. If there was some sort of attachment to them this anime could've easily been bumped up to about a 7. From there the next problem was the story line. A story should not be this confusing. There was no real explanation of what happens, and why everything is happening. Sadly you can't just leave us here expecting us to decipher the whole situation, if that was fixed, then it could've been all the way upto an 8. Overall, this anime was pretty decent, so it gets a 5 from me.

What can I say about glasslip that hasn't been said yet? While it does have decent art and music, the story didn't stand out much. In my opinion, this anime would be categorized as either a slow-paced romance or simplified slice of life.
First of all, The story's quite... mediocre. Don't get me wrong, I like the romance part of it all, but it's just that it's too predictable. It didn't really get my heart pumping. And I think it wasn't right to add "magic" into the show. There was literally no point to it. It was just there for the sake of diversifying the simpleplot. Probably the only part I liked about the wholes series was episode 12. The others, bunch of crap.


Don't even get me started with the characters. They're all pretty much a copy of every shoujo manga character. And like I said before, the romance was predictable. From the start, I knew who was gonna end up with who. They didn't even bother to add some kind of conflict to the story. It's just them getting together and that's it. The end.


Again, if it wasn't for the classical music and simple art style, I would have ranked this a 3. And I definitely don't recommend it if you're looking for a new anime to watch. Believe me, it's a waste of time.

The amount of hate for this show is staggering, its extremely low score almost made me pass on it. So while I did set my expectations low, I ended up really enjoying everything about it. And that's despite being completely oblivious to its allegories. I guess I was a bit bothered by ambiguity of the ending but I didn't find it nearly as bad as everyone makes it out to be. 
My friend pitman (as well as many others I'm sure) think Glasslip is boring, but that view is completely beyond me, especially since those people like ''just relax back and enjoy the cute moe''no-plot healing type of shows. I don't see how can Glasslip then be more boring than those, when it has some romance drama on top of gorgeously drawn SoL setting and moegirls  to hnng for really strongly. Hell, I feel it could be a show just about watching Sachi read  and I'd enjoy it just for how pretty and cute it is.


Pitman was also bothered by Glasslip trying to have some sort of love polygon that he felt was too convoluted and introduced some supernatural plot device that wasn't explained.


To which I answered that Glasslip actually straightens out the love polygon rather quickly and it boils down to 3 pairs. Everyone seems to be bothered by the supernatural element, funny since everyone says almost the same thing about Golden Time supernatural element. I didn't mind either, as I understood that they weren't actually supernatural elements but were rather just meant as creative artistic expression of something that can't easily be expressed otherwise. In Golden Time it's representation of what it feels like to have split personality. Having the other personality drawn and animated characterizes it as a separate entity, something that wouldn't work nearly as well with just ''hearing a voice in his head''. In case of Glasslip: 


 Reddit quote: Because of their love, because of their fears, and because of their sensitive nature, Touko and Kakeru experience and share their emotions through imagination, otherwise known as ''fragments of the future''. It has nothing to do with alternate worlds, fates, other dimensions, timelines, or other bullshit - it's just their vivid imagination. They learn about each other and about each other's feelings and emotions this way. 


Funny enough, Kill la Kill is what opened me up to enjoying this type of allegorical/non-literal storytelling (as well as some of bobduh's writeups possibly). I used to dislike it before hand, though I still do if it's completely over my head like in Yuri Kuma Arashi since that just makes me feel stupid for not getting absolutely anything at all...

Glasslip is... well, I don't quite understand it much, but it's about a group of third year high students undergoing their summer vacation-- which is the final summer vacation they will have as high schoolers for they will graduate after that school year ends. Two of these said teenagers possesses abilities of some sort that allowed them to see/hear the "future fragments".
It all started with five "close" friends from childhood who often hangs out, and stuff like that (the normal squad stuff). It all changed when Okikura "David" Kakeru came in town claiming that he saw the same thing as Fukami Touko, our MC, duringthe fireworks festival from the start. And starting from there, the group started going separate ways and don't seem to be as close as they were before.


My opinion in this is this: if their friendship is that easy to break, then were they even close in the first place?


Moving on to the characters, the MC Touko is... well... I would say shallow. She actually fell for David after she only met him. Or maybe it was because they possess the same abilities? Or maybe because she saw the "future"? I wouldn't know, but it does happen in real life. 


She has this ability to see the future (I don't know if what she can see is future though, but for this review's sake, let's just say that she can see the future), it is triggered whenever she looks at reflective, shiny things (namely, glass).


In general, she is this string who holds the group together and the group fell apart because her, being the string, was taken by David, who she spent most of her time with. 


David is quite a stoic and serious boy, at times he can be blunt and straightforward. He is also perceptive but is insensitive to people's feelings, so he ends up saying too much and whatnot. David has two other alternate egos, to whom he talks to about his problems. He hops from place to place because of his Mom's job, he happened to be in this town and saw the same thing Touko did, which intrigued him.


He has the ability to hear the future, it occurs whenever he hears his mother's classical music.


There's Imi Yukinari who liked Touko, a runner from the track team, and his step-sister, Takayama Yanagi, who liked Yuki. At first, it confused me as to why they were living together, and I had to look up that they were actually step-siblings, they should really explain that one from the start geez. I still wonder why they have different surnames though. Anyway, Yuki is the guy who is almost always seen with a scowl, he is also jealous of David at the beginning. Yana is the pretty one, although I sometimes get the bitter vibe from her.


I'll go over to Nagamiya Sachi, a frail bookworm who may or may not have romantic feelings for Touko, and Shirosaki Hiro, who is in love with Sachi. I actually find him sweet. Well, Sachi harbors feeling of hatred towards David for being the reason their group falls apart. But I'm glad that Sachi is gradually falling for Hiro, so it's all good.


The art and music is amazing and the effects are almost flawless. The art is what I see as the strong part of this anime. I like the frozen frames in each episode (the ones when it pauses and portrays the scene as an amazing drawing). The ending of ep 13 which showed all the frozen frames is very enjoyable.


On the whole, this anime is not so good, the plot is all over the place, and there are a lot of things that are left unexplained. Personally, there are scenes that just made my eyes roll, and there are also scenes where I was like "What just happened?". I do recommend it if you like good art, because the art is just fantastic.

Well here is a review of Glasslip:
Well how should i put it into words as it was completely shit and i mean it. Glasslip is a romantic comedy slice of life show for which the most part i don't get it as the story is way too predictable and the main protagonist is pieceofshit without any emotions and for the most part a pain in the a** and i don't get the idea of paring each one of the characters as i hate this kind of thing.As for the character development there was too little in it and the character was pretty much generic.
Well forthe good part the animation was done by P.A Works and was pretty good for the most part and for the sound it was good but not outstanding and this is all i can say about this anime as it could have been pretty good if the would have explained it a bit more and answer the questions that were unanswered.


As for the anime i don't recommend it but if want to watch it then do as you please!!

Remember those high school classical literature texts that teachers assigned for literary critique? Remember those stories that could be interpreted in countless ways due to their vagueness, hinted symbolism, and usage of metaphors? Well welcome back to high school; your assignment for the next six and a half hours is to work your way through this slow and perplexing work of art. It is a work of art because I'm certain that if you look at it from certain angles, you will find beauty. However, whether that glimmer of beauty is worth it is obviously up to the viewer. If you can deal with aslow story and like the challenge of having to think to figure out what is happening, this might be a candidate for watching. If you like your conclusions and hearty plot chunks served nice and warm on a clean plate stay clear of this one.


Glasslip follows the daughter of a glassblower, Touko, and her group of friends, who have agreed to a pact of no relationships. This pact rapidly shatters (pun intended) with the arrival of Kakeru, a confident yet childishly ignorant transfer student who suddenly claims to understand Touko in ways that her other friends don't. Kakeru claims that Touko's occasional hallucinations when she sees shiny things (such as glass) are fragments from the future, and as we know, you have to be careful when playing with glass shards. How will Kakeru affect everyone's relationship with each other, and will he be able to solve the mystery of Touko's shards?


Animation:

If there is one category that immediately shouts beautiful, it's this category. The artwork in this work borders and even supersedes the quality of some animated movies. P.A. Works has obviously spared little here; the background is filled with lush details and the overall scenery, a rural small-town, combined with the calming music and sound effects create an atmosphere truly worth envying. This is proudly on display from the get go with some of the best fireworks animations I have yet seen. Though the overall quality is very similar to what was seen in Nagi no Asukara, the focus this time is squarely on the town rather than the sea. Some of the scenes, such as the morning seaside scene at the beginning of episode 6, are absolutely breathtaking; from the reflection of gentle, incoming waves, to the calm dew enveloping the landscape, you just can't help but feel a sense of calm and utter relaxation. Looking beyond the general background and lighting, P.A. Works has also put their special touch on the characters. All of the characters are well styled and well animated. What I love about P.A. Works is probably the subtle details that they focus on with their characters, whether it is a slight off-glance in response to a remark or the many emotions that Touko goes through while figuring out how to open a bottle of Ramune. The characters are all distinct though Touko's reddish-eyes and pale skin would almost make one think this would be a fit for a vampire flick.


This is neither an action nor an ecchi show, unless you count girls in simple school swimsuits as ecchi. Do expect a punch or two and some kissing though.


Sound:

The sound of this show beautifully complements the animation. The show starts with a fittingly calm and melodic piece by ChouCho and ends with a more livelier piece by Nano Ripe (I still don't like her high-pitched, nasal voice though). Even more impressive for me is the great BGM that brings in the OP and ED as well as some other orchestral pieces that are both melodic and memorable. The instrumentation is relatively light compared to some other works but it is nonetheless very effective. Add on a nice set of sound effects including a multitude of seaside waves and chirping cicadas and you have a very compelling sound package.


To be honest, the VAs in this work are relatively junior in comparison to Nagi no Asakura. This shows a bit as Yanagi, voiced by Saori Hayami, clearly is the strongest character in terms of clarity and presence. While nothing was particularly annoying, Kakeru's ambivalent voice and personality was just a bit too reminiscent of Yuu from Persona 4 for my tastes. Overall, not the best VA work I've seen from P.A. Works but it still gets the job done.


Story:

Going in to this show, I had already sensed the beginnings of a bumpy road with a lot of negative reactions to early episodes. A quick Reddit search confirms suspicions with people claiming that finishing this show was just as harrowing of an endurance as watching Haruhi's infamous endless eight. To be fair, the show was quite ambitious in its goals and the overall execution wasn't all that focused. We all know that if you try to multitask too much you end up getting nothing done, and certain parts of this show certainly felt that way. Most perplexing is the fact that, despite trying to accomplish so much, the show came across as tortoise slow. Perhaps the slowness is due in part because of the calming, serene atmosphere and perhaps it's due in part because the director spent all the time focusing on the tiny moments that I so enjoyed. Regardless, if you venture into this, prepare to give your full, undivided attention if you want to make sense out of much of the show; and prepare for bits to still not make sense afterwards (two full viewings in my case).


So as I mentioned earlier, Kakeru is a cue ball traveling full speed towards a group of five other billiard balls (two striped and three solids), and the resulting collisions take up the full length of the show, and whether or not any of the balls end up in holes is for the viewer to figure out. The previous sentence is both a metaphor not unlike what you will encounter in the show as well a description of the main plot and rather incomplete conclusion. You will encounter much in this adventure including references to literature that I have never read, chickens conveniently named after philosophers (other than Jonathan), sudden sound effects that sound as if they came straight out of Another accompanying supposedly supernatural events, and some slice of life romance mixed in as well. If you get confused along the way, I recommend stopping and looking at a map (figuratively); attempting to plow further will most likely just get you even more lost. And here's the deal breaker for most of you, even when you reach the end of the road you will find neither a pot of gold nor a harem of seventy two virgins, you just find a dead end. The series forces you to retrace your steps to hypothesize on, but to be honest they leave few foreshadows.


In summary, though the show has its moments, many of the plot elements felt thrown in for the heck of it, and the story doesn't really get its message across, whatever it is supposed to be; it rather just drops you off on a random ditch with a few glass beads for your trouble.


Character:

Story aside, the show does have well-developed characters and some fairly good interactions. Like Nagi no Asukara, the story revolves around multiple characters all with their own subplots, and like Nagi no Asukara you have a group of established friends whose fate becomes intertwined with an outsider, who seemingly tugs at certain female group members. However, Touko (who reminds me of a much more attractive version of Manaka) aside, the characterizations are very different and the relationships much more subtle in general. Here's a hint, if you watch the OP, you'll already have a good idea of where much of the relationships are going. They give that to you as a freebie, what you have to figure out the themes and meanings outside of the relationships.


The only thing that can really spoil one's rating here would be the viewer's impressions of Touko and Kakeru. Touko is a simple girl and one who is slow at quite a lot. A lot of viewers will find this not as cute but rather off-putting. Kakeru is cast as an lone wolf who thinks of attachments as troublesome, yet he is somehow surprisingly keen at times when it comes to social sense. As the majority of the show is told from their perspectives, a strong distaste for either character will leave quite a sour aftertaste; and judging by the character votes on Anidb, most people do feel this way. For me, I was able to work through Touko's shortcomings and enjoy her attempts at resolving the group's issues in her own way. However, Kakeru is still an utter mystery; his decisions don't seem to follow any traceable path and his overall ignorant/confident attitude just completely throws me off.


If there is a saving grace, it's the strong character of Yanagi, who is seriously the only character (Hina aside) with a good amount of emotional maturity. I guess I should also point out that at least some of the parents play a role in the show and that there are relatively few additional supporting characters, both nice pluses. However, the pluses are mired by uneven growth and ultimately unsatisfying romance.


Value:

This series was truly difficult to review, and I had to commit to watching the entire thing twice before I felt I had enough of the fragments to form a worthy review. Glasslip is a beautifully drawn work with great atmosphere and music. In that way, it is very similar to K, another show with great presentation but questionable storytelling. The story that Glasslip tries to tell is something of a mess. Yes there are some cute moments but overall you feel like you're trying to draw water out of an empty well. However, if you can see yourself liking the characters, then at least not all is lost. Though I enjoyed the show with its interactions and animation, I know that many will not find that as reason enough to watch this. And quite honestly, I feel that the show could have been so much more. If you really like P.A. Works and have shoveled through blizzards such as Red Data Girl, you might as well trudge on with this one. But alas, if you do not fall under this category, this show is probably one that you should probably pass.
